intro: Absinthium canariense, commonly known as Canary wormwood, is a flowering plant native to the Canary Islands. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces small, oval-shaped seeds that are dispersed by the wind. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often growing in rocky or coastal areas. Due to its historical use in herbal medicine, it has also been cultivated for its aromatic properties.
distribution_native_art_desc: Absinthium canariense is primarily native to the Canary Islands. It is found in the volcanic soils of Tenerife, Gran Canaria, and Fuerteventura. This plant thrives in dry, sunny environments and is commonly found in coastal areas and open grasslands. It is an important part of the local flora and has adapted to the unique climate of the region. Due to its restricted habitat, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
